H0.text: Flooding is the factor that most likely results in an area where surface sediment is not porous, thereby limiting how much rainwater is absorbed.

H1.text: Droughts are most likely to result in an area where surface sediment is not porous, because when rain falls on land some of it is absorbed by surface sediment and the porosity of the sediment controls how much water is absorbed.

H2.text: Tornadoes are most likely to result in an area where surface sediment is not porous, because when rain falls on the land some of it is absorbed by surface sediment and the porosity of that sediment controls how much water is absorbed.

H3.text: Spring formation is the condition that most likely results in an area where surface sediment is not porous.

A4.text: Floods occur when ponds, lakes, riverbeds, soil, and vegetation cannot absorb all the water.

A5.text: Saturation of the soil by groundwater sufficient to prevent or hinder agriculture.

A6.text: When stress is applied that causes densification due to water (or other liquid) being displaced from between the soil grains, then consolidation, not compaction, has occurred.

A7.text: Affected soils become less able to absorb rainfall, thus increasing runoff and erosion.

A8.text: During flooding, saturated soil can become oxygen-depleted if it stands stagnant for long enough.

A9.text: Because of regular flooding, floodplains frequently have high soil fertility since nutrients are deposited with the flood waters.
